Situation1: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Situation2: A sudden route closure forces dozens of flights into tight holding stacks around the airport.
Story: I stare at the radar screen, my headset pressing into my temples, the air thick with the voices of pilots requesting instructions. The route closure has thrown the airspace into chaos—planes circling, fuel ticking down, every second demanding my full attention. My supervisor’s voice crackles in my ear, reminding me that safety is everything. But my phone vibrates in my pocket, a message from Mia: “We need to talk. I can’t keep fighting like this.” My chest tightens. We’ve argued every night this week about money, about how I never seem present, about how she feels alone. I know she expects me to fix this, to be the boyfriend who listens and makes things right. But right now, dozens of lives depend on my focus. My mind splits—one half calculating flight paths, the other replaying her words, her tears. I can’t be in two places at once, but both demand all of me. My hands hover over the controls, my heart pounding, caught between the chaos in the sky and the storm at home.
